title: 115_hr4668
content: The Act may be cited as the "Small Business Advanced Cybersecurity Enhancements Act of 2017". Small businesses, comprising over 97% of total businesses in the US, are crucial to various sectors like finance, transportation, power, water, and healthcare. Many lack dedicated IT departments and often outsource or assign IT duties to employees. The Internet Crime Complaint Center reported 298,728 cybersecurity-related complaints in 2016, with a total of 3,762,348 complaints since 2000. Cyber attacks on small businesses are a significant concern, with 71% occurring in businesses with fewer than 100 employees. Only 14% of small- and medium-sized businesses feel equipped to handle cyber risks. The Better Business Bureau found that half of small businesses could only remain profitable for one month if they lost essential data. Cyber crime is rapidly growing, with global costs estimated to exceed $2 trillion by 2019. Cybersecurity is a global challenge that continually evolves with new threats and techniques. Collaboration between public and private sectors is crucial in combating cyber crime. Small businesses are hesitant to share information with the government, so proactive measures are needed to incentivize information sharing for improved cybersecurity. Enhanced cybersecurity assistance and protections are being implemented for small businesses. The Small Business Act is amended to establish small business cybersecurity assistance units in coordination with various government agencies. The Small Business Act is amended to establish a central small business cybersecurity assistance unit that serves as the primary interface for small businesses to share cyber threat indicators and defensive measures with the Federal Government. The Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act of 2015 allows small business concerns to share cyber threat indicators and defensive measures with the Federal Government through a central small business cybersecurity assistance unit. The Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act of 2015 allows small businesses to share cyber threat indicators and defensive measures with the Federal Government through a central small business cybersecurity assistance unit, which is collocated with the national cybersecurity and communications integration center. The central small business cybersecurity assistance unit, established under subparagraph (A)(i), collaborates with regional units to provide cybersecurity assistance to small businesses and utilizes resources from various government departments. The central small business cybersecurity assistance unit collaborates with government departments to improve cybersecurity posture and disseminate actionable information to small business concerns. The central small business cybersecurity assistance unit works to disseminate cost-effective methods for implementing the cybersecurity framework to improve small business cybersecurity posture. Input is sought from the Office of Advocacy to prevent regulatory burdens on small businesses. The text discusses enhancing cybersecurity protections for small businesses by leveraging resources and relationships with national cybersecurity entities. No cause of action can be taken against small business concerns regarding cybersecurity practices. The text states that no legal action can be taken against small businesses for actions related to authorized cybersecurity activities or responses to cyber threats shared under the Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act of 2015. The exception in the Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act of 2015 does not apply to cyber threat indicators or defensive measures shared by small businesses. The Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act of 2015 does not apply to legal actions against entities that are not small businesses. Definitions for 'cyber threat indicator' and 'defensive measure' are based on CISA. The term 'national cybersecurity and communications integration center' refers to a specific establishment under section 227. The term 'national cybersecurity and communications integration center' refers to a specific establishment under section 227 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002. SEC. 4. PROHIBITION ON NEW APPROPRIATIONS. No additional funds are authorized for this Act and its amendments. Existing funding from the Small Business Act will be used. A technical amendment is made to allocate funds for cybersecurity assistance units at small businesses. Funds may be used for portable assistance for startup and sustainability non-matching grant programs by small business development centers. The non-matching grant for small business development centers in economically challenged communities is capped at $100,000 and is intended for personnel expenses. The non-matching grant for small business development centers in economically challenged communities is capped at $100,000 for personnel expenses and related small business programs and services.
